newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RUGBY UNION-AUSTRALIA BEAT ILL-DISCIPLINED FRENCH.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-AUSTRALIA BEAT ILL-DISCIPLINED FRENCH.

text.p: Australia rugby union coach Greg Smith said his team had done France a favour by beating them 26-19 in the second and final test on Saturday.
Smith said the Five Nations champions could learn from their experience during a short tour to Australia after losing the test series 2-0.
Smith created a furore before the second test at Ballymore by claiming the touring side were guilty of deliberately flouting the rules in a misguided attempt to disrupt the Wallabies.

"I know they have reacted fairly angrily to what I said but we are trying to do them a bit of a favour," said Smith, who has accused French players of repeatedly breaking the offside rules and illegally trying to spoil their opponents' possesion.
"I am talking about violations against the spirit of the game. I think they will benefit from what they have learned over here," said Smith.
Australia, who won 29-15 in Sydney a week ago, stunned the touring team with an early assault during which prop Richard Harry, winger Ben Tune and centre Jason Little all scored tries.

That gave the home side a 17-0 lead inside the first 20 minutes and although French centre Christophe Lamaison brought his side back into the match with a fine kicking display, Australia defended superbly late on to protect their lead.
The match was marred by a number of ugly incidents that prompted Welsh referee Clayton Thomas to twice warn rival captains about their sides' conduct.
In the worst incident, back rowers Troy Coker and Fabien Pelous wrestled each other to the ground before the Australian forward landed several punches to his opponent's head.
Coker said he was provoked after accusing Pelous of deliberately trying to gouge his eyes in a ruck.
"When you've got someone's knuckle buried in your eye socket, the first thought is self-preservation," Coker said.
Pelous earned a further warning from Thomas when he felled Wallaby flanker David Wilson with a high tackle.
French lock Olivier Brouzet was also penalised for stamping on Wallaby flanker Brett Robinson at the fringe of a ruck just before halftime.
France's only try was scored by Thomas Castaignede in the 36th minute to reduce Australia's lead to 20-13 at the interval.
"In that spell before halftime we came close to producing the form that won us the Five Nations championship but we could not maintain that," Benazzi said.
"We are very disappointed to lose two test matches in a row and we were unable to recover our balance after Australia scored those early tries."
Lamaison kicked four penalties and one conversion to keep the French in a match that was marred by ill-discipline from both sides.
His accuracy brought the touring team to within one point of the home side at 20-19 early in the second half before Eales landed two of his three penalties to put the match out of France's reach.
